channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2021 The New York Times Company

item.title: What Went Wrong With Covax, the Vast Global Vaccine Program
item.description: After months of struggle, the U.N.-backed Covax alliance will soon have many more doses, promising relief for vaccine shortages in poorer countries. But it faces a deepening crisis: difficulties getting shots into arms as the Delta variant spreads.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Mueller and Rebecca Robbins
item.media:description: Carrying a box of vaccines this spring in Goma, in the Democratic Republic of Congo. The country received 1.7 million AstraZeneca doses through Covax in March, but distribution is another challenge.

item.title: Olympic Sprinter From Belarus Seeks Refuge in Japan, Fearing Jail at Home
item.description: Belarus tried to force the sprinter, Kristina Timanovskaya, to return home after she criticized her coaches for registering her for the wrong event.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.media:description: Kristina Timanovskaya with Japanese police officers at Haneda Airport in Tokyo on Sunday.

item.title: Top Myanmar General Says Military Rule Will Continue Into 2023
item.description: Six months after seizing power, the junta’s leader on Sunday extended a state of emergency for two more years. Protesters said they would persevere.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Beech
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: A rally on Thursday in Yangon, Myanmar, against military rule. People across the country have been gathering for brief protests, then dispersing before the security forces can crack down.

item.title: Riots Shatter Veneer of Coexistence in Israel’s Mixed Towns
item.description: Israel’s Jewish and Palestinian communities looked past each other until violence and bloodshed forced a reckoning.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:credit: Dan Balilty for The New York Times
item.media:description: Seventy-three years after Israel’s birth in the 1948 Independence War, in which hundreds of thousands of Arabs fled or were driven out at gunpoint, Jews and Arabs in Israel live side by side but largely blind to each others’ lives.

item.title: Police in China Detain Canadian Pop Star Kris Wu on Suspicion of Rape
item.description: Kris Wu, a 30-year-old celebrity, is the most prominent figure in China to be held over #MeToo allegations.
item.dc:creator: Amy Qin and Elsie Chen
item.media:credit: Christopher Katsarov/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Kris Wu performing at a music awards show in Toronto in 2018.

item.title: As Fears Grip Afghanistan, Hundreds of Thousands Flee
item.description: With the Taliban sweeping across much of the country, at least 30,000 Afghans are leaving each week. Many more have been displaced within Afghanistan’s borders.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum and Fatima Faizi
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: With the security situation in Afghanistan rapidly deteriorating, hundreds of people wait in long lines at the passport department in Kabul each morning.

item.title: Body of Reuters Photographer Was Mutilated in Taliban Custody, Officials Say
item.description: The body of Danish Siddiqui, a Pulitzer Prize winner killed in Afghanistan, was unrecognizable when it was brought to a Kandahar hospital, one official said.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: A tribute to Danish Siddiqui in New Delhi on July 17, the day after his death.

item.title: Hong Kong Targets Student Unions to Tame Universities
item.description: The authorities are clamping down on universities, which they consider hotbeds for unrest. The groups say they are fighting for survival.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang
item.media:description: Police carrying material out of the student union office at the University of Hong Kong on July 16.

item.title: With Undersea Robots, an Air Force Navigator Lost Since 1967 Is Found
item.description: A recovery mission off Vietnam’s coast showed how advances in technology have given new reach to the Pentagon’s search for American war dead.
item.dc:creator: Mike Ives
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Preparing to launch one of three robotic vehicles to survey the seafloor off Vietnam in February 2020. The search led to the recovery of an Air Force navigator’s remains.

item.title: Hong Kong Arrests Anthony Wong Yiu-ming for Singing at Election Rally
item.description: Anticorruption officials arrested Anthony Wong Yiu-ming, a Cantopop singer, who has publicly supported the Chinese territory’s pro-democracy opposition.
item.dc:creator: Austin Ramzy
item.media:description: Anthony Wong Yiu-ming, shown here in 2019, is one of the few celebrities who have spoken out against the Hong Kong government and its backers in Beijing.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: French protests over Covid passes.
item.dc:creator: Whet Moser
item.media:description: A protester holds a poster reading 'Freedom' during a demonstration against the COVID-19 health pass which grants vaccinated individuals greater ease of access to venues in Paris on Saturday.

item.title: What is An Olympic Gold Medal Actually Worth?
item.description: Some former Olympians have resorted to selling their medals because of financial hardships or to raise money for charity.
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor
item.media:description: Sunisa Lee of the U.S. holds her gold medal. Even though the sentimental value may be priceless to the athletes who wear them, Olympic medals are finding their way to pawn shops from the podium.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: Afghans are fleeing the Taliban advance.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: With the security situation in Afghanistan rapidly deteriorating, hundreds of people wait in long lines at the passport department in Kabul each morning.

item.title: Delta Variant, R.S.V. Infections Rising Among Children
item.description: An outbreak of respiratory syncytial virus, combined with growing Covid-19 pediatric cases, is straining hospital resources in some U.S. cities.
item.dc:creator: Jesus Jiménez
item.media:credit: Jose A. Alvarado Jr. for The New York Times
item.media:description: A student in New York last month. Rising cases of Covid-19 and respiratory syncytial virus are straining pediatric resources in parts of the United States.

item.title: N.I.H. Director: Proof of Vaccination Is Step in 'Right Direction'
item.description: Businesses and government agencies are pushing employees to get vaccinated amid a surge in new coronavirus infections across the country.
item.dc:creator: Jesus Jiménez
item.media:description: Dr. Francis Collins, director of the National Institutes of Health, in May.

item.title: Russia Scoffs at Tokyo Olympics Ban: ‘Let Them Listen to Classical Music’
item.description: Sports fans and officials in the country have no trouble seeing through the thin fiction of a doping-related ban on their national symbols at the Tokyo Olympics.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Nanna Heitmann for The New York Times
item.media:description: Outside the Luzhniki Stadium in Moscow on Saturday. With humor and pride, Russians are gloating over their athletes’ many medals this summer despite a prohibition on their nation’s symbols at the Tokyo Games.

item.title: ‘X’ Marks the Spot: Officials Map a Route Out of the Pandemic
item.description: Governments and organizations around the world are using geospatial data and digital mapping tools to guide their vaccination campaigns.
item.dc:creator: Emily Anthes
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dr. Harsha Rajashekharaiah, a senior project coordinator for Suffolk County’s Covid-19 response. “One of the common questions I used to get was, ‘Where is it bad?’” he said.

item.title: Tunisia’s President Holds Forth on Freedoms After Seizing Power
item.description: “‘Why do you think that, at 67, I would start a career as a dictator?’” President Kais Saied said in a meeting with The New York Times, quoting Charles de Gaulle. He vowed to preserve hard-fought rights.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.media:description: President Kais Saied of Tunisia, center, leading a security meeting with members of the army and police forces last week in Tunis.

item.title: Even the Pope Has Prayed to Venezuela’s Beloved ‘Doctor of the Poor’
item.description: In a deeply polarized country, suffering an extreme health crisis, one of the few uniting beliefs is the admiration across the political spectrum for a doctor recently beatified by the Vatican.
item.dc:creator: Meridith Kohut and Isayen Herrera
item.media:description: Devotees carrying an image of Dr. José Gregorio Hernández during a procession through the streets of Isnotú, the small town in Venezuela where he was born in 1864.

item.title: Texas Governor Bars Mask and Vaccination Mandates
item.description: The state’s daily average of cases has risen more than 200 percent over the past 14 days and hospitalizations are surging, but an executive order ensures that masking and vaccinations remain voluntary.
item.dc:creator: Dave Montgomery
item.media:credit: Ilana Panich-Linsman for The New York Times
item.media:description: A restaurant in Austin, Texas, in April.

item.title: In Vaccine Holdout States, a New Urgency to Administer Shots
item.description: Data from the C.D.C. shows that many people in states like Louisiana, Mississippi and Missouri are now receiving their first doses. On Friday, more than 850,000 total shots were recorded in the U.S.
item.dc:creator: Eduardo Medina
item.media:description: Ayana Campbell, 14, received a Covid shot at Jackson State University in Mississippi on Tuesday.

item.title: Thousands Protest in France Against Health Pass for 3rd Weekend
item.description: The government’s health pass law was passed by Parliament and is expected to get a final greenlight from a top constitutional council next week.
item.dc:creator: Aurelien Breeden
item.media:description: Demonstrators in Paris protested France’s health pass and other coronavirus protocols on Saturday. Similar protests took place in other cities, including Marseille, Rennes and Strasbourg.

item.title: Biden Promised to Restore the Iran Nuclear Deal. Now It Risks Derailment.
item.description: Both sides have much to lose if a delicate negotiation over limiting Iran’s activities in return for a lifting of sanctions falls short.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger, Lara Jakes and Farnaz Fassihi
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:description: The Biden administration’s approach to a nuclear deal has become complicated with the election of a new conservative leader in Iran.

item.title: Stranded Killer Whale Survives With Help of Good Samaritans
item.description: Rescuers and wildlife officials kept it cool and wet while waiting for a rising tide. The orca returned to sea about six hours after it was spotted on the rugged shores of an Alaskan island.
item.dc:creator: Alyssa Lukpat and Jacey Fortin
item.media:credit: Captain Chance Strickland and Crew of M/V Steadfast, via NOAA Fisheries.
item.media:description: An orca stranded on the rocky shore near Prince of Wales Island in Alaska. The tide eventually came in and it swam away.

item.title: Key Afghan City in Danger of Falling to the Taliban
item.description: Government reinforcements arrived Saturday in Lashkar Gah, the capital of Helmand Province, but people were fleeing their homes and a hospital in the city had been bombed.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Taimoor Shah
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lashkar Gah, Afghanistan, the capital of Helmand Province, in May.

item.title: U.S. Shifts Tactics Against Virus in Days With Mask Guidance
item.description: Delta-driven surges are prompting new measures from the federal government, states and cities, companies and the military, as well as defiant rejections.
item.dc:creator: Lauren McCarthy
item.media:description: A commuter wearing a face mask arriving in downtown Chicago on Tuesday.

item.title: The Long Kiss Goodbye: Will Covid End the French Bise Forever?
item.description: Social distancing made the cheek kiss a much rarer greeting, and polling suggests it may stay that way. Some say good riddance, but others miss the warmth of times past.
item.dc:creator: Gaëlle Fournier
item.media:description: In 2010, Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain and his wife, Samantha Cameron, greeted President Nicolas Sarkozy of France and his wife, Carla Bruni-Sarkozy, with a bise in London.

item.title: Mourning Families Seek Solace From the ‘Grief Purgatory’ of Covid-19
item.description: The pandemic has left hundreds of thousands of Americans alone in bereavement, unable to plan proper funerals for their loved ones. Now, they’re planning larger celebrations of life.
item.dc:creator: Eduardo Medina
item.media:credit: Joseph Rushmore for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jessica Zimmerman-Selvidge holding a drawing of her father, Ralph Zimmerman, who died at the height of the pandemic.

item.title: The Blue Jays Finally Return to Canada
item.description: With a pandemic-forced sojourn to Buffalo and Florida now complete, Toronto’s exciting young team got a chance to experience its actual home crowd.
item.dc:creator: Alex Wong
item.media:description: A crowd of 13,446 attended the Toronto Blue Jays’ win over the Kansas City Royals on Friday. It was the first regular season game in Toronto since 2019.

item.title: In South Africa, Poachers Now Traffic in Tiny Succulent Plants
item.description: Police search the desert trying to track down the poachers selling Conophytums to collectors worldwide, threatening to wipe out rare plants in the wild.
item.dc:creator: Tommy Trenchard
item.category: Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species

item.title: Three Olympic Refugee Team Members Will Call Canada Home
item.description: The athletes will join another 150 refugee students selected who were accepted to one of 80 participating institutions this fall.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Paulo Amotun Lokoro, right, and Yiech Pur Biel, both middle-distance runners from South Sudan, in Rio de Janeiro in 2016.

item.title: Murder Trial in Sweden Could Shine Unsavory Light on Iran’s New President
item.description: Nearly 3,000 miles from Tehran where mass executions were carried out in 1988, a murder trial in Sweden could produce new revelations that complicate life for Iran’s president-elect.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Deaths From Covid in Africa Are Rising as Cases Surge Worldwide
item.description: “We can prevent this disease, we can test for it, and we can treat it,” said Dr. Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, director general of the World Health Organization.
item.dc:creator: Daniel E. Slotnik
item.media:description: People waiting to receive coronavirus vaccines at Léopold Sédar Senghor stadium in Dakar, Senegal, on Wednesday.

item.title: Delta Variant and Travel Restrictions in Europe: What to Know
item.description: Curfews, vaccine requirements, conflicting advice. As variants like Delta spread, rules and restrictions are popping up across the continent and staying informed can feel like a job.
item.dc:creator: Ceylan Yeginsu
item.media:description: At Berlin Brandenburg Airport, passengers stand next to signs for a Covid-19 testing center.

item.title: Here’s who is hospitalized for Covid in New York City.
item.dc:creator: Sharon Otterman
item.media:description: Two sisters from the Order of the Missionaries of Charity walking in Brooklyn, N.Y., where cases are rising.

item.title: Vaccinated People May Spread the Virus, Though Rarely, C.D.C. Reports
item.description: The agency cited an outbreak in Provincetown, Mass., in which most of the infected were immunized. An internal C.D.C. document paints an even more harrowing picture.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: A dose of the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine being administered at a three-day clinic in Wilmington, Calif., on Thursday.

item.title: Spanish Court Targets Chilean Bank Tied to Pinochet
item.description: Spurred by victims of Gen. Augusto Pinochet’s regime, the court has reopened an investigation into whether Banco de Chile helped the former Chilean dictator launder money.
item.dc:creator: Raphael Minder
item.media:description: Gen. Augusto Pinochet in Santiago, Chile, in 1997. He died in 2006.

item.title: Greece Accuses Aid Groups of Helping Smugglers of Migrants
item.description: Greek police claim some groups have worked with smugglers and provided migrants with details about Coast Guard activities. The groups deny the charges.
item.dc:creator: Niki Kitsantonis
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Discarded life vests, inner tubes and rubber rafts, used by refugees to cross into Greece from Turkey, on the Greek island of Lesbos in 2015.

item.title: U.S. restaurants scramble to reimpose rules.
item.dc:creator: Christina Morales
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yu Wu serving dim sum at Pacific Palace restaurant on Eighth Avenue, a commercial strip in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, N.Y., in March.

item.title: Wildfires in Turkey Rage on, Firefighters Struggle to Contain the Blaze
item.description: The Turkish authorities said they were investigating the causes of fires that killed at least six people and threatened popular tourist destinations.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier and Asmaa al-Omar
item.media:description: A firefighter extinguishing a forest fire near the town of Manavgat, Turkey, where the fires first broke out this week.

item.title: Israeli Officials Say Iran Is Behind Deadly Attack on Oil Tanker
item.description: Drones carried out the attack on a tanker managed by an Israeli-led firm, killing two people, officials said — apparently the latest in a series of maritime clashes between Iran and Israel.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley and Ronen Bergman
item.media:credit: Johan Victor/Johan Victor, via Associated Press
item.media:description: The tanker Mercer Street in 2016 off the coast of South Africa. It was attacked Thursday night near Oman.

item.title: Remains of Esther Dingley, Missing British Hiker, Are Found
item.description: For months, the authorities and Ms. Dingley’s partner combed the Pyrenees mountains. A DNA test confirmed the identity of remains found near her last known location, a group aiding the search said.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor
item.media:description: Remains of the British hiker Esther Dingley, who went missing in the Pyrenees in November 2020, were found, according to a group aiding the search.

item.title: Los Angeles Schools Will Test All Students and Staff for Covid
item.description: The shift by the second-largest U.S. district comes weeks before in-person classes are scheduled to resume.
item.dc:creator: Lauren McCarthy
item.media:description: Kindergarten students in Los Angeles on the day in-person learning resumed in April.

item.title: More Covid Mysteries
item.description: There’s much to learn about how the virus spreads.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: Pedestrians in central London this week.

item.title: How Europe, after a fumbling start, overtook the U.S. in vaccinations.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier and Josh Holder

item.title: The Delta variant is a ‘serious threat’ as contagious as chickenpox, the C.D.C. finds.
item.description: An internal agency document paints a grim picture of the fast-spreading coronavirus variant, saying it appears to cause serious illness and health officials must “acknowledge the war has changed.”
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.media:credit: Scott McIntyre for The New York Times
item.media:description: In Miami Beach, Fla., on Wednesday. The C.D.C.’s new masking guidelines, introduced on Tuesday, were based on information presented in a document about the Delta variant.

item.title: Wooden Buildings Reach for the Sky
item.description: Ambitious high-rise projects in Sweden are a showcase for a reviving forest industry.
item.dc:creator: Gabriel Leigh

item.title: Martine Moïse, Haitian President’s Widow, Recounts Assassination
item.description: Struck by gunfire, Martine Moïse lay bleeding as the assassins who killed her husband ransacked her room. Now, she says, the F.B.I. must find the mastermind behind the attack.
item.dc:creator: Frances Robles
item.media:credit: Maria Alejandra Cardona for The New York Times
item.media:description: Martine Moïse, first lady of Haiti, in Florida on Thursday. Her husband’s assassins also shot her in the arm.

item.title: Nanjing Delta Outbreak Tests China's Tough Approach to Covid
item.description: Cases have spread from the city of Nanjing to several provinces and the capital, Beijing, in the past three weeks.
item.dc:creator: Paul Mozur
item.media:description: Waiting for Covid-19 testing in Nanjing this month. About 200 cases have been reported in an outbreak centered on the city as of Friday.

item.title: The Indigenous Archaeologist Looking for Residential School Graves in Canada
item.description: Kisha Supernant has brought radar technology to the search for burial sites in Canada while she works to reshape her profession’s relationship with Indigenous communities.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Amber Bracken for The New York Times
item.media:description: Professor Supernant’s beaded pin was created by a Métis artist.

item.title: Afghan Visa Applicants Arrive in U.S. After Years of Waiting
item.description: The first group of Afghan interpreters and others who helped Americans during the war will stay on an Army base in Virginia until they are resettled.
item.dc:creator: Eric Schmitt and Jennifer Steinhauer
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: Afghan interpreters who worked with the U.S. military protesting visa delays in front of the American Embassy in Kabul last month.

item.title: Hong Kong Protester Is Sentenced to 9 Years in First Security Law Case
item.description: Tong Ying-kit, 24, who drove a motorcycle into police officers while carrying a protest flag, was convicted of terrorism and inciting secession.
item.dc:creator: Austin Ramzy
item.media:description: A van took Tong Ying-kit to a Hong Kong courthouse on Friday for his sentencing.
